turns.utterance: Do you read the newspaper? I do occasionally, but just don't think about it with the computer and all
turns.response: Newspapers are important instutions.  I believe we have to support them if we want any sort of investigative journalism.

turns.utterance: that makes sense, there would be no need for journalism without newspapers, I am sure they have been around for decades
turns.response: YEah some even so trusted enough to become the "Newspapers of Record" which means their journalism is trusted enough to be consensus fact.

turns.utterance: Wow, that is interesting, do investigative journalists earn a lot every year?
turns.response: They can make about $45,000 a year, definitely more that the aforementioned "Newspapers of Record" like The New York Times and Boston Globe and such.

turns.utterance: That is not bad pay at all, do they require any special training or schooling?
turns.response: Oh yeah you gotta go to one of the premier journalism schools, to learn how to cover things like politics and business, even weather.

turns.utterance: Oh well that does make sense, the weather guy.. what is the terminology for them again? I forgot they go to school to do that, it would be hard to learn all the words and phrases they use
turns.response: Weather reporters are called Meterologists.  And despite their constant criticism for "getting things wrong" they are prized members of any journalism outfit.

phrase: like i said before im not one to read an actual newspaper but i do like reading opinion and political articles.
